div.p: A SHORT CATECHISME, SVMMARILY COMPRIZING THE Principall points of Chriſtian faith, ſomewhat corrected and augmented by IAMES BALMFORD Minister.
div.q: Prou. 24. 27. Prepare thy worke without, and make ready thy things in the field, and after build thine houſe.
div.p: AT LONDON, Imprinted by Felix Kyngston, for RICHARD BOYLE. 1607.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFVLL, THE Maſter, Wardens, Aſsistants, and whole company of Carpenters in London, IAMES BALMFORD, a Carpenters ſonne, and a builder, according to his calling and gifts, wiſheth the continuall edification of their godly faith while they trauaile in this vale of teares, and at the last the end of that faith euen the ſaluation of their Soules.
div.p:
THis litle Catechiſme hath been long in Print, but not yet dedicated vnto any. Being now to reprint it with other litle treatiſes, I haue thought it conuenient to dedicate it vnto you, as a monument of my thankefulnes for your many fauours, but eſpecially for your
charitable exhibition, when I was a poore ſtudent in Oxford; Hoping that this dedication wil not only incourage you to continue, and increaſe (as God ſhall inable) your Chriſtian charitie to Students of good hope in either Vniuerſitie (than which I know not a more charitable, and fruitfull worke of faith) but alſo ſtirre you vp both to reade the Catechiſme diligently your ſelues, & carefully to cauſe your families to learne it. For it is commonly ſeene; that (howſoeuer too many be newfangled, yet for the moſt part) men are rather moued with thoſe Treatiſes, which are expreſſely & ſpecially addreſſed vnto thēſelues, and that by ſuch as, in ſome ſpeciall ſort, belong vnto them. This only I deſire, that ye would take ſome paines in examining the
quotations, becauſe they giue both light vnto the vnderſtanding, and warrant to the confirmation of the ſeuerall points of this Catechiſme.

I doubt not of your good wil; but whereas this Catechiſme is likely to come into the hands of ſome, who will not, with you, intertaine it fauourablie for my ſake, I ſuppoſe this obiection: One generall, and well conceiued Catechiſme doth moſt edifie; therefore many are but to litle purpoſe: Whereunto I readily and freely anſwere; That, hauing experience how profitably the ſtudies of children haue been furthered, ſince diuerſitie of Grammars hath been aboliſhed, and one certaine Grammar generally to be taught, by act of Parliament eſtabliſhed, I grant that one generall and well conceiued
Catechiſme doth moſt edifie, in reſpect of publike vſe: But I am aſſured, that, as ſundry Grammars, ſo ſundry Catechiſmes doe much good in priuate ſtudie, and vſe. For the ſame method of teaching which ſeemeth to ſome plauſible & pleaſant, plaine and profitable, doth not ſeeme ſo to other; And one Catechiſme doth more cleerely lay opē ſome points of Chriſtiā faith, than another, yea handleth ſome neceſſary point, which another doth altogether omit. Againe, It helpeth much to the confirmation of faith, when it is ſeene, that, howſoeuer ſundry men in ſundry ages & countries, publiſh ſundry Catechiſmes, or make ſundry confeſſions (betweene which two there is no great difference) as to ſay with Iohn Baptiſt, Behold the Lambe of Joh. 1. 29.
God which taketh away the ſins of the world; or with Peter, Thou art the Chriſt the Sonne of the liuing God, the one publiſhing his office, the other confeſſing his nature; yet they hold the ſame Head, belieue in the ſame Chriſt, iuſtifie the ſame Wiſedome, and profeſſe the ſame Truth. What great profit do Gods children reape by the Harmony of cōfeſsions, as of Churches, ſo of ancient and late writers? What benefit hath, and doth redound to the Church of God by ſundry Creeds, not only extant, but ſome of them in publique vſe too, as the Apoſtolique, Nicene, and Athanaſian, euery one doth know, and acknowledge. In theſe conſiderations I conceiue hope, that this litle Catechiſme will bee offenſiue to none, but acceptable to you, and profitable to all ſuch, as with religious
humilitie will vſe, & peruſe it. And the rather, becauſe they ſhall find the moſt neceſſary doctrine of the Lords Supper more plainely ſet downe in this Catechiſme, than in many other of no greater volume.

Well, what good opinion ſoeuer this Catechiſme ſhall find in the hearts of other Readers, let me exhort you as a brother, to edifie your ſelues, with all holy diligence, eſpecially in hearing the Word preached, and (as you may) in reading firſt the Scriptures, and then other Godly Treatiſes; Vnderſtanding that Edification, ſo much commēded and commanded in Holy Writ, doth ſignify Building. Of which ſpirituall building, your temporall building ſhould daylie put you in mind; Leſt otherwiſe yee incurre a cenſure and ſentence,
like to that of the Prophet Haggai, Hag. 1. 4. 6. 1. Cor. 3. 9. 16. viz. Can yee build houſes for your ſelues, and other; and will yee careleſſely ſuffer the Temple of the Lord (which is your ſelues) to lie waſte? Yee ſhall therefore earne wages, and put them into a broken bag. But hoping (as I wiſh) that yee will more and more apply your hearts vnto wiſedome, euen that wiſedome which is vnto ſaluation, I commend you to God, and the Word of his grace, which is able to build further, and to giue you an inheritance among all thē which are ſanctified.

div.head: A ſhort Catechiſme, neceſſarie to be learned of all Chriſtians.
div.p: Q. WHo is the Creator and gouernour of this world?
A. Geneſ. 1. Eſay 45. 5. One God, in whom there bee thrée perſons, 1. John 5. 7. the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost.
Q. Of all viſible creatures which is the chiefeſt?
A. Geneſ. 1. 26. Pſal. 8. 5. Man.
Q. After what manner made hee him?
A. Geneſ. 1. 26. Like vnto himſelfe.
Q. How was that?
A. Eccleſ. 7. 31. Epheſ. 4. 24. Frée from ſinne, and perfect in righteouſnes.
Q. To what end made hee him righteous?
A. Pſal. 119. 73. Eſay 43. 7. To ſerue him.
Q. Did man continue righteous?
A. Geneſ. 3. 6. 7. 10. No: he ſell from righteouſnes to ſinne.
Q. How did he fall into ſinne?
A. Geneſ. 3 6. 7. By cating the forbidden fruit.
Q. What abilitie was left in man to ſerue God after that ſinne?
A. Geneſ. 6. 5. Ierem. 4. 22. Epheſ. 4. 18. None at all, either in knowledge or affection.
Q. Did that ſinne reſt in Adam alone?
A. Iohn 3. 6. Rom. 5. 12. No: it deſcendeth from him into all mankind.
Q. What fruites doth it bring forth in all mankind?
A. Geneſ. 6. 5. Rom. 5. 12. &c. Sinfull thoughts, words, and déeds.
Q. What is the puniſhment due for ſinne?
A. Geneſ. 2. 17. Rom. 6. 12. & 6. 23. Euerlaſting death and damnation.
Q. How come we to the knowledge of ſinne?
A. Rom. 3. 20. By the Law.
Q. Wherunto ſerueth this knowledge?

A. Act. 2. 37. & 24. 26. 1. Cor. 14. 24. 25. To humble man, and to caſt
him downe in the conſideration of his owne miſerie.
Q. How is it poſſible for man to be ſaued in this miſerie?
A. Matth. 1. 21. & 11. 28. Act. 4. 12. & 10. 43. By Ieſus Chriſt.
Q. What is Ieſus Chriſt?
A. Rom. 9. 5. Matth. 1. 23. God and Eſay 9. 6. Man in Gal. 4. 4. one perſon.
Q. Wherefore was he man?
A. Gal. 4. 4. 5. Heb. 2. 9. 10. 11 To do thoſe things which were to be done for mans redemption.
Q. What be they?
A. Philip. 2. 7. 8. 9. 10. His ſuffering, Matth. 5 17. righteouſnes, & 16. 28. and triumphing.
Q. Wherefore was he God alſo?
A. Hebr. 9. 14. Coloſ. 2. 9. &c. That the doings of his manhood might be of infinite vertue.
Q. Why did Chriſt ſuffer death?
A. Rom. 3. 24. 25. To be our Iustification. In acquiting Coloſ. 2. 13. 14. 15. vs of our ſinne, 1. Pet. 1. 18. 19. by diſcharging the puniſhment due thereunto.
Q. Why was Chriſt righteous?
A. 1. Cer. 1. 30. 31. To be our Sanctification, in making Iohn 17. 19. vs holy in ſome meaſure, Exod. 28. 38. and to couer the imperfection of our holines.
Q. What benefit inſueth that Iuſtification and Sanctification which we haue by Chriſt?
A. Rom. 1. 16. 17. & 6. 13. Euerlaſting life which Adam loſt by ſinne.
Q. What be the doings of Chriſt his triumph?
A. 1. Cor. 15. 55. 57. Reſurrection from death, and Epheſ 4. 8. Aſcention into heauen.
Q. Why did he ariſe from death?
A. Rom. 4. 25. & 8. 34. To ſeale the merits of his ſufferings for our Iustification, 1. Cor. 15. 57. and to ouercome death for vs.
Q. Why did he aſcend into heauen?
A. Rom. 8. 34. To make continuall interceſſion to procure Hebr. 7. 25. ſauing helpe, and to Iohn 14. 1. 2. take poſſeſſion for vs.
Q. How are we made partakers of theſe foure meritorious workes of Chriſt, to wit, his Death, Righteouſnes, Reſurrection, and Aſcention?
A. Iohn 3. 16. Philip. 3. 9. 10. By a true Faith.
Q. What is Faith?
A. Hebr. 10. 22. 11. 1. 1. Tim. 1. 15. 16. A full perſwaſion that God is merciful to me for his Son Chriſt his ſake.

Q. If a true faith bee ſuch a perſwaſion,
who then bee partakers of thoſe foure meritorious workes of Chriſt?
A. True faith is alwaies ſuch in it owne nature, but beleeuers are not alwaies ſenſible of ſo great a comfort, becauſe of their infirmities.
Q. May I craue ſome proofe hereof for my confirmation, & comfort?

A. Conſider well, 1. The quoted proofes of the deſcription of Faith. 2. That otherwiſe it ſhould not differ, either frō Opinion Luke 24. 21. 25. Act. 26. 28. 29. which in it owne nature is doubtfull, or from the Diuels faith Iam. 2. 19. which trembleth, becauſe it doth not apply. 3. That the Godly Pſal. 27. 13. & 77. 9. 10. Ma • ke 9. 24. 2. Cor. 12. 7. 8. 9 haue acknowledged as much. 4. What power 1. Pet. 5. 5. 6. 7.
Faith is of to preſerue true beleeuers from deſpaire, their great feares notwithſtanding. And 5. That it is therefore Rom. 8. 15. 16. 26. 27. Matth. 14. 30. 31. like vnto the Spirit of Prayer, which the faithfull diſtreſſed feele weake in themſelues, but find ſtrong in the effect.
Q. How may we know when we haue a true faith?

A. When wee know that our
faith t is grounded on Gods Word; Rom. 10. 14. 17. Philip. 4. 4. 5. 1. Pet. 1. 6. 8. Reioyceth in the Lord more or leſſe; but alwaies vnſeignedly, notwithſtanding croſſes and tribulations; and Mat. 7. 18. 20. Galat. 5. 6. Iam. 2. 18. In loue bringeth forth good fruits, which are good workes.
Q. What calleſt thou good workes?
A. Mat. 19. 16. 17. Thoſe which God requireth in the ten Commandements.
Q. What if good workes be wanting?
A. Iam. 2. 20. 21. 26. Titus 1. 16. Then is inſtifying faith wanting whatſoeuer we profeſſe.
Q. Can good workes iuſtifie?
A. Iob. 29. Iam. 2. 18. They iuſtifie in declaring vs to be iuſt before men, Rom. 3. 27. 28. & 4. 2. 5. 6 but they do not iuſtifie in making vs iuſt before God.
Q. Why ſo?
A. Gal. 3. 10. & 5. 3. 4. 17. Hebr. 12. 13. Becauſe they are not perfectly done of vs.
Q. To what purpoſe ſerue they then?
A. Matth. 5. 16. To glorifie. God, 1. Pet. 2. 12. and profit our brethren.
Q. Touching our ſelues what vſe haue they?
A. 1. Tim. 1. 5. Iam. 2. 22. They are certaine ſignes of vnfained • aith▪ Rom. 2. 6. 7. and of GOD are well rewarded.
Q. If good workes be rewarded, then they merite, if they merite, then they iuſtifie?
A. Rom. 8. 17. 18 They are rewarded for Chriſt his ſake, Hebr. 10. 36. 2. Cor. 1. 20. and becauſe of Gods promiſe, Luk. 17. 7. 8. &c. but not for their owne worthines
Q. How are Faith & good works begun in vs?
A Rom. 10. 14. 17. By preaching of Gods word, and working 1. Cor. 12 3 4 2. Cor 4. 13. of his holy Spirit.
Q. How are they increaſed▪ and continued in vs?
A. Eph. 4. 1. &c. 2. Cor. 3. 18. By the ſame meanes, and further by the vſe of the Rom. 4 11. Sacraments and Marke 9. 24. prayer.
Q. What are the Sacraments?
A. Rom. 4. 11. Holy ſignes and ſeales of Matth. 26. 26. &c. 1. Cor. 12. 13. Ieſus Chriſt▪ and his benefits.
Q. How many Sacraments bee there?
A. 1. Cor. 10. 2. 3 & 12. 13. Two: Baptiſme, and the Supper of the Lord.
Q Why be there two Sacraments and no more?
A. Hebr. 9. 15. Becauſe the maker and Mediator of the new Rom 11. 27. Couenant Matth. 28. • 9. 1 Cor. 11. 23. 25 ordained theſe and no more, Marke 1. 4. as ſeales of the ſame.
Q. What difference is there betweene theſe two?
A. Baptiſme ſignifieth our new Titus 3. 5. birth, or entring 1. Cor. 12. 13. into the Couenant: and therefore we are but once baptiſed.
Q. How doth the Supper of the Lord otherwiſe ſignifie?
A. Our ſpirituall féeding or continuance in the Couenant, and therfore Act. 2. 42. 46. & 20. 7. 1. Cor. 11. 24. 26 we receiue often, and not only once at Eaſter, which is Leuit. 23. 6. Iewiſh.
Q. Why are children baptized?

A. 1. Cor. 7. 14. Becauſe they be the ſéed of the faithfull, and therefore Gen. 17. 7. within the viſible Couenant, ſo that the ſeale thereof is to be Act. 10. 44. 47. Gen. 17. 11. 12. adminiſtred vnto them.
Q. Why receiue they not the Supper of the Lord?
A. 1. Cor. 11. 28. Becauſe they cannot examine themſelues.

Q. Of how many things doth a
Sacrament conſiſt?
A. Two: a ſigne perceiued Mark. 1. 4. • . 1. Cor. 11. 23. & 10. 25. 2. 3. 4 by ſenſe, and a thing ſignified, not at all perceiued by ſenſe.
Q. In Baptiſme which is the ſigne, which is the thing ſignified?
A. Act. 8. 36. Water the ſigne: Chriſt his blood Eph. 5. 25. 26. Hebr. 9. 14. the thing ſignified.
Q. Whath doth the waſhing of the body ſignifie and ſeale vnto vs?
A. Act. 22. 16. Rom. 5. 9. & 3. 24. 25. The waſhing away of our ſinnes by the blood of Christ, which is our Iustification.
Q. What doth it elſe ſignifie and ſeale vnto vs?
A. Rom. 6. 3. 5. 1. Cor. 6. 11. The reforming of our actions and affections in the name of Christ, Gal. 3. 27. 24. Epheſ. 4. 23. which is our Sanctification.
Q. In the Supper of the Lord, which is the ſigne, which the thing ſignified?
A. 1. Cor. 11. 23. 24. 25. Bread and wine the ſigne, Chriſt his body and blood the thing ſignified.
Q. What ſignifieth the breaking of the bread, and powring of the wine?

A. 1. Cor. 11. 24. The breaking of his body
and Marke 14. 24 ſhedding of his blood.
Q. What doth the eating and drinking ſignifie and ſeale vnto vs?
A. Pſal. 104. 15. That as bread and wine preſerueth our naturall life: ſo Iohn 6. 54. Chriſt his body and blood is our ſpirituall food vnto eternall life.
Q. How ſo?

A. Becauſe Christ is our continuall 1. Iohn 1. 7. 9.
Iustification and Rom. 8. 10. 11. Sanctification.
Q. Why calleſt thou the body and blood of Chriſt ſpirituall food?
A. 1. Cor. 10. 3. 4. Ioh. 6. 35. 63. Epheſ. 3. 17. Becauſe it is ſpiritually receiued by faith, not corporally eaten with teeth.

Q. Are not the body and blood of Chriſt called ſpirituall food, becauſe the ſubſtance of bread & wine is tranſubſtantiated into the ſubſtāce of Chriſt his very body and blood, though only the accidents of bread and wine remaine and be ſeene?
A. No: For ſuch a Tranſubstantiation, is moſt contrary to this ſpirituall banquet, for thrée reaſons.
Q. Which be they?

A. If there be ſuch a Tranſubſtantiation,
then this Sacrament ſhould want the outward ſigne. For the accidents; without the ſubſtance of bread and wine cannot nouriſh, and therefore there is no ſigne perceiued by ſenſe, to ſignifie ſpirituall feeding, not perceiued by ſenſe.
Q. What is your ſecond reaſon?

A. This Trauſubstantiation being a miracle, ſhould bee euidently ſéene (as was Joh. 2. 8. 9. 10. 11. the tranſubſtantiation of water into wine at the mariage in Cana) for confirmation of the word, eſpecially in a Sacrament. Seeing both Marke 16. 20 miracles, and Rom. 4. 11. Sacraments be called Signes, in regard of ſuch confirmation.
Q. What is your third reaſon?

A. By ſuch Tranſubstantiation, the ſuppoſed ſpirituall food, ſhould be a body and blood preſently made of bread and wine, and not the body and blood of Chriſt crucified, and long ſince Galat. 4. 4. made of a woman, which this ſpirituall banquet doth ſignifie, and ſeale vnto faithfull receiuers.

Q. If there be no ſuch Tranſubſtantiation,
how then can wee eate Christ his very body, and drinke his very blood, which are bodily ſubſtances Act. 3. 21. abiding in heauen, and that only by faith ſpiritually?

A. As they who acknowledge his Maieſtie to bee their only ſoueraigne, and do accordingly ſubmit themſelues vnto his gouernment, become members of the ſame politique body, whereof his very perſon is head: So they Ioh. 1. 12. & 6. 35. 37. Act. 4. 12. Epheſ. 4. 13. 15. who by faith profeſſe Chriſt to be their only Sauiour, and do accordingly committe themſelues to his ſaluation, become members of the ſame myſticall body whereof his very perſon is the head.
Q. You ſpeake now of the whole perſon, & incorporation; but before of the body and blood of Chriſt, and feeding.

A. As 1. Cor. 12. 13. Epheſ. 5. 23. Ioh. 15. 1. 4.
Incorporation, and other borrowed ſpeeches of Holy writ, ſo & 6. 56. 1. Cor. 10. 16.
Feeding ſignifieth our ſpirituall cō munion with Chriſt, yet with ſome further conſideration.
Q. What is that?

A. To teach vs that we are incorporated
into Ioh. 12. 32. 33 Rom. 6. 3. Chriſt crucified. As wee are fedde with the fleſh of beaſts not liuing, Act. 10 13. but ſlaine.
Q. Is not this the reaſon why both bread and wine be neceſſarily diſtributed in the Lords Supper?

A. Yes: and further, 1. Cor. 11. • 3. 24. 25. Matth 19 6. becauſe of the inſtitution: 1. Cor. 11. 26. for a liuely repreſentation of Chriſt his death: Joh. 19. 32. 33. 34. differing from the thieues death: Leuit. 7. 2. and anſwering to the ſacrifices: Pſal. 104. 1 • . Ioh 6. 35. 54. 55. and for the comfortable aſſurance of our perfect nouriſhment.
Q. Is not then our perfect nouriſhment another conſideration of our ſpirituall feeding, beſides our incorporation into Chriſt?
A. Yes: for Io • 6. 57. if we eate Chriſt, we ſhall liue by Chriſt, and & 4. 49. 51. 52. that (as it were) with health, & 15. 4. 5. which is the effect of ſuch incorporation.
Q Expreſſe this yet more fully.

A. As he who corporally feedeth with good digeſtion, feeleth his heart Act. 14. 17. 1. King. 19. 7. 8 gladded, and the whole man better inabled to performe the actions of naturall life: So be who ſpiritually féedeth by a true faith, feeleth Rom. 5. 1. 2. the
peace of conſciente, and Galat. 2. 20. John 6. 57. the whole man better inabled to performe the actions of a ſpirituall life.

Q. Then I perceiue that the Scripture vſeth borrowed ſpeeches in regard only of Eating and Drinking, and not of Christ his body & blood; becauſe our communion▪ though really and verily with Christ himſelfe crucified, is yet by the ſpirituall meane of a true faith.

A. It is ſo; As may be euidently ſéne in the 6. chapter of Iohn ſo often quoted. For whereas in the 54. verſe Chriſt ſaith, Whoſoeuer eaſeth my fleſh, and drinketh my blood hath eternall life; in the 35 verſe he ſaith, He that commeth to me ſhall not hunger, and he that beleeueth in me ſhall neuer thirst. So that F • eding▪ Comming, and Beleeuing are manifeſtly▪ th •• caſe, all on • , And conſequently our receiuing of Christ crucified muſt of neceſſity be ſpirituall. As it further appeareth in the 12. verſe of the firſt chapter of the ſame booke.

Q. All that come to the Lords table, do they ſpiritually receiue the
body and blood of Chriſt?

A. No: The wicked receiue only
• uke 1 • . 26. 27. & 22. 14. the ſignes▪ to their damnation, not Iohn 13. 2. & 6. 35. the things ſignified to their ſaluation.
Q. Why ſo?2. Theſſ 3. 2.
A. M • t 8. 11. 12. 1 Cor. 11. 27. Becauſe they receiue vnworthily.
Q. How may we receiue worthilie?

A. By comming to the Lords table with Iohn 6. 35. Faith and 1. Cor. 11. 30. 3 •
Repentance.
Q. What is repentance?
A. A forſaking Ezec. 33. 11. of our ſinnes and turning Jerem▪ 4▪ 1▪ 2. to God, by Matth. 4. 17. amendment of life.
Q. Can we beleeue and repent of our ſelues?
A. Philip. 1. 29. Ezec. 11. 19. No: And therfore we muſt craue Marke 9. 24. Je • em. 31. 18. theſe and all other graces of God by hartie prayer.
Q. What is prayer?
A. Luke 18. 1. &c. An earneſt requeſt to God, in y• name Iohn 14. 13. of Chriſt for all things Iam. 4. 3. neceſſary.
Q. How may we be ſure to obtaine all things neceſſary?

A Mar. 9▪ 22. 33 If we aſke in faith: Matth. 21. 2 •

ſo God hath promiſed. To whom b • glory for euer.

div.head: A PRAYER.
div.p:
O Moſt mercifull and gracious Father, whereas we are not able of our ſelues to perceiue the things of the Spirit, 1. Cor. 2. 14. being naturall men, yea ſo fooliſh Ierem. 4. 22. and of no vnderſtanding, that howſoeuer, we are wiſe to do euill, to do well we haue no knowledge, we moſt humbly beſeech thee for Chriſt his ſake to remember thy Ier. 31. 33. Couenant, and teach vs by thy Ioh. 16. 13. holy Spirit, which ſearcheth all things, 1. Cor. 2. 10. 12. yea the deepe things of God, to know thoſe things which thou haſt giuen vs. Suffer vs not therefore, O Lord, with the 1. Ioh. 5. 19. 20. world to lie in wickednes, but giue vs a mind to know thy Sonne Ieſus Chriſt, who is very God and eternall life. And open our Luke 24. 45. vnderſtanding, that we Iohn 5. 39. ſearching may vnderſtand the Scriptures, which are able to 2. Tim. 3. 14. 15. make vs wiſe vnto ſaluation. And
whereas ſinne Hebr. 12. 1. 2 hangeth ſo faſt on, that we cannot run the race that is ſet before vs, with an eye ſtill looking to Ieſus the Author and finiſher of our faith, with groning ſpirits we intreate thee, to ſeparate them from vs, as far as the Eaſt is Pſal. 103. 12. from the Weſt, that hauing laid a ſure foundation Hebr. 6. 1. of repentance from dead works and faith towards God, we may be led forward to perfection, and hauing learned the doctrine of the beginning of Chriſt, we may grow Eph. 4. 15. 13 vp into him which is our head, vntill we meete together in the vnitie of faith, and knowledge of the Son of God vnto a perfect man, and vnto the meaſure of the age of the fulnes of Chriſt. That ſo growing in 2. Pet. 3. 17. 18 grace and knowledge of our Lord and Sauiour Ieſus Chriſt, we be not plucked away with the error of the wicked, and fall from our owne ſtedfaſtnes: but hauing the righteouſnesRom. 1. 16. 17. of God reuealed to vs from faith to faith, we may perceiue indeed, the Goſpel to be to vs the power of God to ſaluation, and ſo go from ſtrengthPſal. 84. 7. to ſtrength, till we appeare before
God in Zion. Which graces, with all other bleſſings ſpirituall and temporall, for our ſelues and euery member of thy Church, we beg of thee O holy Father in the name and mediation of our Lord and Sauiour Chriſt Ieſus, further recommending our ſelues, our prayers and wants to thy fatherly conſideration, concluding in that moſt holy prayer which our Maiſter himſelfe hath taught vs, ſaying: Our Father which art in heauen, &c.
